Organisms reproduce to pass their genes on to the next generation.
The study of heredity and the variation of inherited characteristics.

# Asexual reproduction
Does not require the production and fusion of [[gamete]]s. Organisms go through a [[Mitosis]] like process to produce offspring.
Pros:
- Offspring auto adapted to environment
- No mate required
- Very fast
Cons:
- Can lead to limited resources
- No genetic diversity

# Sexual reproduction
Reproduction that requires [[meiosis]] and [[Mitosis]].
Parent organisms copulate, [[gamete]]s undergo fertilization and form a single celled zygote.
Pros:
- Allows for genetic diversity
Cons:
- Offspring not adapted to environment 
- Requires energy and time
- Finding a mate can be difficult

# [[chromosome]]s
# [[gene]]

# Genetic Diversity
Where organisms have different traits

[[meiosis]] contributes to genetic diversity among [[gamete]]s in 2 major ways.
- Crossing over during Prophase I allows for new combinations of alleles on chromosomes.
- [[chromosome]]s are randomly sorted into the [[gamete]]s during anaphase, allowing for unique combinations of alleles.

Random fertilization of [[gamete]]s allows for genetic diversity because one is paternal and one is maternal. This allows for different combinations of alleles
# [[Mitosis]] vs. [[meiosis]]

## [[Mitosis]]
- One round of division
- Part of a cycle
- Start and end with same # of [[chromosome]]s
- End result is 2 identical [[Somatic Cells]]
- Mutations are not passed on to offspring

## [[meiosis]]
- Two rounds of division
- Not part of a cycle
- Start and end with different #'s of [[chromosome]]s
- End result is four genetically diverse [[gamete]] cells
- Mutations are passed on

## Similarities
- Overall process of chromosomal segregation is the same.

# Genotype
[[allele]]s inherited from the parents
# Phenotype
Physical traits based on genotype

# Consequences of mutations
Genetic diseases can be diagnosed by looking at a [[karyotype]].
Fertilization involving these [[gamete]]s leads to severe genetic diseases in offspring such as trisomy.

# Pedigree
Pedigrees show the passing of traits through a family lineage. Information from a pedigree can help you determine the inheritance pattern of a trait in a bloodline.



# Non-Mendelian Genetics
Complex inheritance that does not follow the one gene on trait inheritance pattern. May not follow Mendel's laws. Alleles for genes can have many different relationships other than the dominant/recessive pattern.

Many traits do not exhibit the dominant recessive inheritance pattern.
These traits will exhibit different phenotypic and genotypic ratios than mendelian traits.

# [[gene]] linking
The closer two linked [[gene]]s are on a [[chromosome]], the less likely they are to be separated my crossing over.
Linked [[gene]]s assort together during [[meiosis]].
They violate the law of independent assortment.

# Calculating Recombination Frequency
Step 1: determine what the parental and recombinant genotypes are
- Parental genotypes are what show up in the parent
- ex: b+vg+ and bvg
- Recombinant genotypes are those that result from crossing over
- ex: b+vg and bvg+
Step 2: calculate the recombination frequency (RF)
[![GENETICS / RECOMBINANT FREQUENCIES (COV) - Pathwayz](data:image/png;base64,)
Higher recombination frequency means there is a higher chance of crossing over between two [[allele]]s.
Therefore, recombination frequency can be used as a measure of how far apart two [[gene]]s or [[chromosome]]s are.
1% chance of recombination frequency = 1 map unit.

# Co-dominance
The [[allele]]s for a gene are both dominant; the heterozygous individual will express both phenotypes.

in co-dominance there are 3 phenotypes, Heterozygote shows both traits.

# Incomplete dominance
Neither [[allele]] is dominant to the other. The heterozygous individual will express a blend of both phenotypes.

in incomplete there are 3 phenotypes, 
Heterozygote shows a blend of traits.

# Multi-allelic phenotypes
[[gene]]s with more than two [[allele]]s can have more than two phenotypes depending on the dominance relationship between the [[allele]]s
## Blood type
A and B [[allele]]s are co-dominant to each other and dominant to the O [[allele]]

# Polygeneic inheritance
Many traits require groups of [[gene]]s to be expressed concurrently; what phenotype the organism shows is based on the combination of genotypes and the dominance relationship between each [[gene]]/[[allele]] in the process.

Epistasis occurs when one [[gene]] affects how another [[gene]] is expresses

# Sex-linked traits
Some [[gene]]s are linked to the X or Y [[chromosome]]s instead of the autosomes. These [[gene]]s are sex linked.

X linked recessive diseases primarily affect males because they don't have another X chromosome to overpower the disease carrying gene.
Chromosomal females have two X chromosomes and can be carriers of and X-linked recessive diseases.

Some traits are inherited from [[DNA]] found in the [[Mitochondria]] and [[Chloroplast]]s. These traits do not follow Mendelian inheritance rules because organelles are randomly assorted to [[gamete]]s during [[Mitosis]] and [[meiosis]].

[[Mitochondria]] in animals are only passed on from the egg.
[[Mitochondria]] & [[Chloroplast]]s in plants are passed on from the ovule and not in the pollen.

I hate this class so much.

# Phenotypic Plasticity
Environmental factors can affect which genes are being expressed, when they are being expressed, and the dosage amount that is being expressed. Environmental factors do not change the organism's genotype.

# Gene penetrance
The likelihood that an organism will actually express its inherited genotype.

# Gene expressivity
The degree to which the phenotype is expressed in an organism.
Expressivity can be influenced by [[allele]] combination and/or environmental factors.

# Mendelian Genetics
Inheritance that follows a simple one gene, on trait inheritance pattern.
Two [[allele]] types: Dominant & Recessive
Dominant traits mask Recessive traits.

The laws of probability can be used to predict the expected genotype and phenotype outcomes for both Mendelian and Non-Mendelian genetics.

# Law of segregation
A parent gives only one [[allele]] to each [[gamete]] they produce. Which [[allele]] segregates into each [[gamete]] is random

# Law of independent assortment
[[allele]]s for different [[gene]]s that are located on different [[chromosome]]s segregate independently of eachother.

# Monohybrid crosses
Allow you to calculate the probability that an offspring will inherit a certain genotype or phenotype

Genotypic and Phenotypic ratios are based on which inheritance pattern the [[gene]] follows

# Dihybrid crosses
Used to calculate the probability that an offspring will inherit two different traits together.

# Test cross
Geneticists use test crosses to figure out if an organism expressing the dominant phenotype in homozygous dominant or heterozygous.
They cross the organism displaying the dominant phenotype with an organism expressing the recessive trait.
If the offspring all have the dominant trait, the organism is homozygous dominant.
If some of the offspring have the recessive phenotype, the organism is heterozygous.
